is white and cismale and she is a transwoman of color...  I am not accusing 
you of anything but statistically the chances are very good that this is 
coloring your unspoken assumption of superiority for Piers.  She doesn't 
"owe" him anything.

2.  "...corrected him the first time like a adult."  What, so that the rest 
of the first interview could be spent on "Remedial Gender Politics for

for her, why should she have to be blown off topic every time someone says 
something ignorant?  Her appearance was about *her* and her message - not 
about wasting airtime correcting the errors of a man who, as I said in #1,

+TheSLMTube A few tidbits:

"As a community, the trans folk didn't seem very understanding of this 
Piers interview."

Trans people have the right to be offended by being misgendered and to be 
passionate about it. You have the right to think they shouldn't be 
offended/passionate or to not to care about them being offended/passionate. 
That said, walking on eggshells for anyone is just ridiculous in my view. 
Why bother? Also, keep in mind observation bias. All the trans folks that 
didn't care about this historical misgendering weren't on twitter or here 
telling you all about it, because they, well, don't care. 

It was illegal for men to crossdress as women into the 1970's in places. 
The history of transgender rights and law is quite interesting and things 
are truly moving at pace these days. 

"It seems most transexuals were brought up by guardians who had a strict 
sense of what men can do and what women can do..." It's quite mixed in my 
experience. If you have a source, of course, I'll read it. Keep in mind 
this is of course more true in the past for older trans folks as there 
simply was more sexism and more rigid gender roles in the past in all parts 
of society, not just their parents. 

"If the trans community is arguing that taking on the role of a woman is 
all that makes one a woman..." The trans community is generally arguing for 
self identification. You're a woman if you say you're a woman, period. The 
legal establishment's test for gender marker change is generally more 
physical. While it may be possible to have a doctor write you a letter with 
no medical intervention, most would require hormone treatments at a 
minimum. Other states require surgery. At least one state doesn't allow any 
legal gender marker change at all. This case rather humorously brings the 
hypocrisy together:

http://www.wate.com/story/16039917/morristown-transgendered-woman-says-she-went-topless-to-make-a-statement

In your description I saw more of a focus on GRS and parts. Hormones are 
incredibly powerful too and I wouldn't leave them out of your calculus. 
Many trans people, and particularly transmen (for a number of reasons), 
don't have GRS. Testosterone really works a treat for transmen. The 
transformation is rapid and fairly breathtaking.  

If you care this much about the topic, why not read Janet's book? It's 
probably the best trans memoir, with Boylan's book being a close second. 
This readable primer on the intersection of gender and the transgender by a 
science writer at Johns Hopkins University is also very good. 

http://www.amazon.com/Riddle-Gender-Deborah-Rudacille/dp/0385721978/

I myself have left all my researching over the past week or two less sure 
of where I stand. It may be because I live in a major city where people of 
all types, sexual preferences, styles, attitudes, and outlooks openly walk 
the streets, but- we're not in the 1920's where men couldn't wear pink (or 
dresses and skirts for that matter), stay home and take care of kids, never 
cry or play with barbies, be sexually penetrated etc... a man can be as 
feminine as any female, and vice versa (granted, wearing a skirt would 
limit job opportunities etc... [just like being trans]). If 'gender' is 
just a cultural role generally attached to one's 'sex,' that attachment 
seems to have deteriorated so much that one can be a "woman" (to speak in 
this gender-sensitive way) while still being "male" (I would actually go so 
far as to say "man," and the confusion there would be part of my point). It 
seems most transexuals were brought up by guardians who had a strict sense 
of what men can do and what women can do... a way of looking at the world 
that seems to me to be becoming passe (Again, I live in the city). I didn't 
even realize I behave like a 'woman' at times until I started this 
research... to me a woman had always just been an adult biological female 
(with cultural pressures of shaving legs etc) until I was exposed to this 
trans stuff- and I never thought it was a big deal- sure, you got a vag 
you're a girl, whoop-dee-doo... but with all this controversy I'm thinking 
about it more. If the trans community is arguing that taking on the role of 
a woman is all that makes one a woman then there are a shitload of women 
with penises who think they're men in this city. I'm no longer convinced 
that taking on the role of a woman and getting genital surgery makes a man 
a woman.
But the thing is- I don't think it's important. I don't think someone like 
Janet should be offended if someone like me called her man. It doesn't 
change who she (or he) is, and it doesn't change the fact that I could 
appreciate her (or his) existence, even be sexually attracted to her (or 
him) and respect everything about her/him other than the fact that we 
disagree on a subject which he/she happens to hold dear- her/his 
'womanhood.'

In the end it seems this argument is about definitions and semantics, which 
is really quite trying and boring to argue about. And I don't think there 
should be such passion behind it.

+TheSLMTube I think you're overstating the effort involved. If you have 
some kind of understanding that someone is trans (or otherwise gender 
variant) simply ask them what terms to use when talking about their past if 
the topic comes up. If you have no understanding that someone is trans 
there is no need to assume that anyone's gender in the past would be any 
different than the gender they are clearly trying to present. It's likely 
to be much better bet in my experience that the way trans people present is 
the way they also want to be referred to in the past. Talking with trans 
people it's possible to not have a need to go into the distant past and 
there are a number of trans people that would prefer to not talk about this 
difficult time in their lives at all. There is never a need to walk on 
eggshells about anything. Just by breathing I'm sure I'm insulting someone 
or another. Meh. That said, I have every confidence that if someone told 
you in polite conversation they would rather be referred to this way or 
that way you could make the conversational adjustment. 

If you're talking about professional writing, the Associated Press 
Stylebook says:

"Transgender- Use the pronoun preferred by the individuals who have 
acquired the physical characteristics of the opposite sex or present 
themselves in a way that does not correspond with their sex at birth.    

If that preference is not expressed, use the pronoun consistent with the 
way the individuals live publicly."

I'm not claiming any kind of superiority other than having the fortunate 
experience of talking to many trans people over many years. I've found it 
very enlightening, is all, given that this is the focus of what we're 
talking about. I think you'll find that as a community trans folks are very 
understanding having faced down a life of difficult discrimination but your 
mileage may vary.

Needing someone's name is for practical reasons. One's name has pretty much 
nothing to do with their identity, or how they feel.

If I see a wedding ring on someone, I'm not going to ask them if their 
spouse recently died, if they are in an abusive relationship, or wearing 
the ring to avoid romantic pursuits, I will assume they're married, 
content, and will continue under that assumption. I would expect them to 
give me leeway if I was wrong, because there is a baseline of normalcy that 
needs to be expected and accepted, or entire days will be spent walking on 
eggshells everywhere. 

Transsexuals are a group that has been oppressed and hated, and I'm more 
than willing to support the end of violence, poverty, and unemployment that 
mires the community. But just because many members of the community feel 
they need everyone else to believe that having a penis and corresponding 
chromosomes never made them male, and they feel like having other people 
bullied into using whatever words they choose for their own 
self-description, doesn't make me willing to ask everyone what words they 
would like me to use when referring to them in the past present and future. 
And just because some in the trans community may feel like this makes me an 
oppressor, or a bigot, or just ignorant and mean, does not make it so. 

Although the mindstate of a transexual may forever be a mystery to me (just 
as the mind of a female), it's not like I haven't encountered one ever (you 
seem to be claiming some kind of superiority in judgement over me by 
continually telling me to 'talk to a transexual'). I in fact almost dated 
one. Regardless, I could ask a tonne and each could tell me just what 
you've told me, it wouldn't mean much; just because a large portion of an 
oppressed group (I'm not entirely sure how large) expect others to do 
something for them, does not make it insulting or further oppressing if it 
is not done.

Her /sex/ is male. Yes, odds are near 100% that she has XY chromosomes.

Gender is much more complicated than that. I'm going to go a little off 
topic, but stick with me.

Have you heard of intersex persons? They are people who through some 
combination of hormones, chromosomes, and physical genitalia don't fit into 
binary, easy to classify definitions of gender.

An example of this is a person who is biologically XY but can't process 
testosterone. When this person grows up, outwardly they appear female. 
Breasts, labia. They spend their early childhoods raised as girls. However, 
they will never have periods or give birth to children. Their internal 
genitals are not a uterus, but a penis that never developed enough to drop.

Looking at this clinically we have one piece of information that says male, 
one that says female. The bigger picture has this person qualify as neither.

So how do we classify this person? This is where gender comes in.

Does this person identify with the girl label of their childhood? Or do 
they think male is a better fit for them. Their chromosomes say so. Or 
neither, another possibility.

Situations like this really open up this idea that gender is not the same 
as sex. Gender is about self identity.

Like homosexuality, history is full of people who have lived by different 
genders then those assigned to them at birth. Whether by necessity or 
choice, these decisions had a huge impact on their lives.

+Jeremy S. What you're referring to is called secondary sex 
characteristics. Adam's apple, deep voice, pubic hair, wide/narrow hips, 
etc are all caused during initial puberty by the primary sex 
characteristics, which are the reproductive organs. If one is born with 
ovaries, the ovaries secrete high levels of estrogen into the body during 
puberty, causing wide hip bone structure, small stature, smooth skin, only 
a slight drop in the voice, menstrual cycle, etc. If one is born with 
testicles, they secrete high levels of testosterone during puberty, causing 
all of the male secondary sex characteristics like a deep voice, facial 
hair, taller bones, the hips stay narrow, etc.
Secondary sex characteristics (body formation) and primary sex 
characteristics (genitalia/reproductive organs) are in the same category - 
they are both part of one's sex. They have nothing to do with one's gender 
or gender identity. They also have nothing to do with who a person says 
they are, how they feel, or what pronouns they feel comfortable moving 
through the world with.

Also, I've mentioned this elsewhere but possibly not in this thread:  she 
had limited airtime to try to talk about her book in.  How much of that 
airtime should she have sacrificed to correct Morgan's ignorance?  Her 
fifteen minutes on that show is much more precious to her than to him, 
because he's the host and will be there tomorrow and the next day.  She 
just gets those fifteen minutes (she didn't know at the time that there'd 
be a second interview).  So she is thinking, at all times, "How can I keep 
this segment on track, talk about my book, and not get derailed or dragged 
off on a tangent?"  If she had corrected Piers on the spot, yeah, *maybe* 
it would have taken a couple seconds and that's it.  But maybe not.  For 
all she knew, he might have gotten all outraged and "how dare you I'm your 
ally" etc., etc., which would have totally derailed the segment and ended 
any hope of doing what she came there to do:  talk about her book.  My 
guess is, in the heat of that moment, she weighed the alternatives and made 
the flash decision:  let it go, can't afford to waste the time or take the 
risk.  Naturally, later on on social media there was ample time to point 
out his mistake.  I don't see the problem with this.

Gender identity is a person's private sense, and subjective experience, of 
their own gender. As far as Janet is concerned no matter what she did or 
didn't have done or when, she was never a boy. 

She was taking female hormones during the onset of puberty and consequently 
her voice did not significantly drop, she didn't put on muscle mass, and 
her Adam's apple never filled out. They also caused her penis and testicles 
to shrink. Simultaneously her breasts grew and her skin became smoother. 

It is now standard medical practice for young trans women to take hormone 
blockers to delay the onset of puberty and when they are sure they begin 
estrogen shots and anti-androgen meds (spiro, etc.) and are at that point 
effectively hormonally female. 

http://transhealth.ucsf.edu/trans?page=protocol-youth

It's not offensive terminology, it's just vague terminology. Most people do 
not understand the difference between sex and gender, so when Piers asked 
why it's offensive to say that she was born a boy, she should have asked 
"Do you mean as the sex of a boy, or the gender of a boy?" Obviously she 
was born with the sex of a boy, that much is not offensive (or at least I 
don't see how it could be). She probably understood the question to mean 
being born in the gender of a boy, which would raise the assumption that at 
some point she chose to become the gender of a girl. That would be the 
offensive part-she has always felt like a girl on the inside which is 
something nobody else can testify against. She only ever made a conscious 
decision to become a girl at 18 in the sense of her reassignment surgery, 
which should obviously be called Sex Reassignment Surgery because you're 
not changing their gender. See-even people trying to help trans people are 
hurting them by consistently using the wrong terminology!
All that said, I love Janet Mock but this interview was definitely a 
failure. If I could give any advice to her or any other trans advocates, it 
would be to not get offended too quickly before fully understanding 
someone's meaning, and also to always be clear about the words you use.﻿

Gender and sex is different. She will always and forever be genetically a 
man. She can't change that fact, and it is not sensationalizing it to say 
that fact. She felt that her gender did not match her sex, ie her gender as 
a woman did not match the male genetics. So she chose to change her 
outwards appearance to match her gender to reduce the severe feelings of 
gender dysphoria. The problem which people need to realize and be less 
touchy about, is that supporting trans people, does not mean pretending 
that they are not at a genetic level still the opposite sex. (Obviously 
genetic things like intersex and hermaphrodites is a different issue.)

I support rights for trans people, and I believe Janet is as much a woman 
as any other person that was born a woman. It's not belittling or taking 
away her identity as a woman,or calling her a false woman, just to point 
out that she is genetically a man. I believe gender is what you feel in 
your mind and in your heart, it doesn't matter if you have a completely 
male body without gender reassignment surgery, if you tell me you feel in 
your heart and mind you are female I support that. I will treat you like 
the woman that you are.

I think the trans community have suffered a lot of abuse and condemnation 
from all sides, but attitudes are changing and now is the time to meet 
people halfway. It is hard to see allies when you percieve everyone around 
you as an enemy. People's minds have been closed for so long, that the 
trans community also closed theirs as a defense against these attacks. But 
we need to let down the barriers and let people in. Janet should have been 
able to say, "I don't want to talk about that aspect of my life", and then 
react to whatever Piers response was, rather than staying quiet and then 
attacking it later on. As an author she really needs a manager as well, 
someone to talk to the network heads and check that taglines and such are 
not offensive to her.﻿

know about this for the pure intellectual exercise of doing so and treating

LGBT legal rights in the US scales directly with more people knowing other 
LGBT people on some personal level. That is a question and relationship

a number of important legal protections that  transgender people face 
uniquely because of their situation. Changing their gender on their 
driver's license, birth certificate, passport, being able to use the 
bathroom of your transitioned to gender, etc. There are also a great number 
of people afraid to transition because of the discrimination and oppression 
they would face. This is similar situation to gays and lesbians. In decades 
past they were afraid to come out and lived lives of quiet desperation and 
now, in many places, gays and lesbians are able to thrive personally and 
professionally in a way I would have never thought possible. This is a win 
win for everyone. So it will be for transgender people once enough legal 
and social acceptance is in place.

Can we start by acknowledging that Janet Mock has a HUGE amount of pressure 
on her as an advocate for the entire trans community. Her stepping up and 
commanding this position in and of itself is beyond admirable.

But before people jump to call her a 'bitch' because of her criticism of 
the way her original interview was handled by CNN, take a moment to try and 
understand what she was aiming to do in the original interview. She was 
attempting to share her individual trans experience on a mainstream 
platform and her issue arose afterwards when her story was completely 
minimised and tokenised by the use of traditional trans-phobic discourse. 
Statements like "formerly a man" and "a boy until 18" reduce her individual 
trans experience down to something far too simple and evidently very 
problematic and place far too much focus on the physical aspect of 
transgendered bodies as opposed to transgendered lives and trans stories. 
This language does not encourage understanding nor does it do any work to 
enlighten those on the depth and breadth of experiences within the trans 
community. Her surgically created vagina did not make her a women. 18 years 
of self discovery and self acceptance ultimately took her to a pivotal 
point where she was able to finalise her transition. CNN focused on the 
destination and chose to ignore the journey which is what I understand 
Janet's issue to be.

The way the producers dealt with the original segment was without a doubt 
insensitive to the trans community and lacked a degree of understanding and 
caution for the stigma which is attached to the problematic 'was once a man 
- shock horror! - is now a passable woman' discourse which is so often 
employed to translate a generic trans experience through mainstream media. 
She was simply asking to be treated as an individual and for her experience 
as a transgendered woman to be handled with sensitivity and more 
importantly respect - and Piers did not do this. He placed too much 
emphasis on the instance of her 'coming out' to her cis partner and seemed 
almost surprised to discover that upon learning of her past he did not 
reject her, thereby devaluing her trans body and the trans bodies of those 
in her community.

It was a very complicated and nuanced topic that was explored with rather 
minimal attention and tact by CNN. Trans people need a platform to tell 
their OWN stories not opportunities to be tokenised by middle aged, white, 
privileged men. Piers' accusation that in some way Janet was trying to aim 
the wrath of her community at him via Twitter is also ridiculous. I'm sure 
it never occurred to him that the trans community were not simply blindly 
supporting Janet Mock in 'attacking' him but instead that perhaps he had in 
fact offended many in the community by his treatment of Janet's experience 
in this interview and that they personally felt compelled to express this? 
Then for Pierce to go on to berate her in this follow up... He had no 
intention of learning or trying to understand the situation from her 
perspective. Which only goes to show his inability to have dealt with such 
a topic in the first place. His ego was bruised and he was trying to shame 
and belittle her.

I can understand why she expressed that she felt unsafe in this space in 
the original interview. Piers has a reputation for being ignorant and 
hostile and being both trans and a woman of colour there are so many 
cultural factors that made it so difficult for her to express her anger 
with him in the original interview. She had to play the 'nice palatable 
trans woman' because that is what the community expects from their 
advocates. If she was to be confrontational she would have been working 
against her cause so I admired her ability to sit through that interview 
and grit her teeth and bear it. The 'angry black woman' discourse also 
comes to mind here. People just have no idea how hard it is to convey 
yourself in a way which reflects the intentions of an entire community in 
such a small window of time and in this instance she was faced with the 
challenge of representing both the black community and the trans community 
with integrity. 

My only criticism of Janet in this whole situation was her use of profanity 
on Twitter. She could have dealt with her anger in a better way but I 
understand that in the heat of the moment people may lose some clarity on 
the situation at hand.

Instead of persecuting Janet for trying to encourage a higher level of 
sensitivity for the individual experiences of her community maybe we should 
be applauding her for being brave enough in the first place to even stand 
up and have a voice when so many want her, and those like her, to shut up. 
It can't be easy having the weight of an entire community on your shoulders 
and although this was a bit of a messy, mucky situation I think ultimately, 
she handled it the best that she could.  ﻿

It's easy to check almost any scientific journal by searching in google for 
"transexual" and "brain". Most scientific journals that have done studies 
on brains of transgender people show that transexuals, before hormone 
therapy, have certain specific structures in their brain that are not 
similar to the gender they were assigned at birth. And these same specific 
regions are in fact much more similar to the gender they self-identify as. 
It means a person can be born with male dna and genitalia but still have a 
brain with strong feminine structures or born with female dna and female 
genitalia and have a brain with a strong male structures. In which case, 
And it would make sense that the definition of being male or female would 
need to start to include the structure of an individual's brain, since that 
would probably be more important than their bone structure, muscle 
development, or what they have between their legs.
